repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Signatures can be cycled using `<C-s>` when the user enters the floating
window.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3e704096-826b-417d-9859-ed8cea0b6bcf)

comment_data.body: Can we just hardcode `markdown` here? What if a client sends documentation as plain text?

comment_data.body:
I normally trigger signature help when in insert mode:
```suggestion
      vim.keymap.set({ 'n', 'i' }, '<C-s>', function()
```

comment_data.body: The `a` is for active_offset. I would have used `start` and `end` but `end` is a keyword so I added a single letter prefix. We could go with `s` and `e`. As their scope is very small, so I don't think longer names are justified.

comment_regular_data.body: Feel free to bikeshed on UI and keymaps.

> Feel free to bikeshed on UI and keymaps.

Yeah I don't like using `<C-s>` since I use that to escape and save .

I think it would be nice to cycle through the signatures when calling the function again, although that's currently used to focus the window (although who needs to focus sig help?).

> I think it would be nice to cycle through the signatures when calling the function again, although that's currently used to focus the window (although who needs to focus sig help?).

Note the mapping is for the floating buffer, and not the original buffer. Adding mappings to the original buffer is off the cards since it interferes with user mappings. I believe we need custom modes in order to add mappings to the main buffer. I chose `<c-s>` because that's the default value to open and enter the window. Once you are in the window, you can repeat the key to cycle signatures.

Calling the function again might be possible, but would be more complicated since we need to store a closure somewhere. And we wouldn't be able to show help for the mapping.

The alternative is to not cycle and just dump out all the signatures in a single buffer like we do for hover.

EDIT: this might actually be a good application for `<Plug>` mappings.

> Note the mapping is for the floating buffer, and not the original buffer. Adding mappings to the original buffer is off the cards since it interferes with user mappings. I believe we need custom modes in order to add mappings to the main buffer. I chose `<c-s>` because that's the default value to open and enter the window. Once you are in the window, you can repeat the key to cycle signatures.

Understood. But then cycling would only be possible if you set `focusable` to true right? If that's the case, I would remove the cycling labels when `focusable` is set to false.

> Calling the function again might be possible, but would be more complicated since we need to store a closure somewhere. And we wouldn't be able to show help for the mapping.

Something nice about this is that then we could cycle through the signatures without having to jump into the buffer first. But this design wouldn't allow focusing the buffer.

> The alternative is to not cycle and just dump out all the signatures in a single buffer like we do for hover.

I don't like this since a single server can also return multiple signatures, so this would be noisy.

> Could always use c-w w to focus the window.

Just note that re-using the same mapping, used to show the float, to enter it, has become a bit of an unwritten convention. I've seen it requested in both gitsigns.nvim and hover.nvim.

> (I'd even consider cycling for hover too)

Off-topic, but I'm hoping we can eventually sherlock hover.nvim (in a better form) into something like `vim.hover`, similar to how `vim.diagnostic` relates to LSP diagnostics, so we can include non-LSP hovers: e.g. vimhelp, man pages, diagnostics, in addition to providing an API for plugins to add their own hovers. Normally I'd say this is out of scope, but as we already provide `vim.lsp.buf.hover()`, I think this would be worth doing.

> I'm hoping we can eventually sherlock hover.nvim (in a better form) into something like `vim.hover`

Seems like it would fit in `vim.ui.hover`

> Just note that re-using the same mapping, used to show the float, to enter it, has become a bit of an unwritten convention

Unfortunately - I'm not a fan of these extra mappings when some that are not really harder to use already exist - especially if it then blocks using these keys for potentially more useful behavior.

> Off-topic, but I'm hoping we can eventually sherlock hover.nvim (in a better form) into something like vim.hover, similar to how vim.diagnostic relates to LSP diagnostics, so we can include non-LSP hovers: e.g. vimhelp, man pages, diagnostics,

Could this use the lsp subsystem via https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24338 ?

> Unfortunately - I'm not a fan of these extra mappings when some that are not really harder to use already exist - especially if it then blocks using these keys for potentially more useful behavior.

I'm mostly indifferent, but what is _common_ should be taken into account. I can see the argument that `<C-w>w` is a bit clumsy, but a counterargument to that could be something like `noremap <C-q> <C-w>w`.

> Could this use the lsp subsystem via https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24338 ?

Yeah, potentially. I remember you suggesting it. Arguably, we could have made the same argument for doing that instead of implementing `vim.diagnostic`. We can prototype both, but I expect a dedicated interface will provide more flexibility since we'll be able to reason about Nvim buffers, extmarks, additional mappings, etc, instead of the interface just being `'markdown'|'plaintext'`
